_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Diffusion System & Emergency Refrigerant Control Box

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Wonderful Citrus Packing, LLC is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This
commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program
addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with
the process equipment at the facility.

Wonderful Citrus Packing, LLC senior management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to
maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees
and the surrounding communities. Wonderful Citrus's safety and environmental policies as they
relate to the ammonia refrigeration systems are administered by the Manager of Technical Services,
who conducts inspections of the facility to ensure compliance.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Rio Grande Juice Facility is located at 702 East Expressway 83, in Mission, TX, which is
on the south side of the expressway, between South Conway Avenue and Business Park Drive. The area
immediately surrounding the facility is Urban. The facility was constructed and began operations in
1969.

The primary business of Wonderful Citrus is processing and storage of citrus products. In order to
conduct operations, the facility maintains two refrigeration systems containing a maximum of 18,800
pounds of ammonia, a regulated substance. The Main System contains a maximum of
17,000 pounds of ammonia and the second (separate) Tank Area System that contains a maximum of 1800 pounds of
ammonia. The refrigeration systems, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycle ammonia
through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high
pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the
processing and storage of citrus products. Typical operating conditions range from

:
The Main System: approximately 39 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 300.0
psig on the high side.
The Tank Area System: approximately 58 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 250.0 psig on
the high side.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION
STEPS

The The Rio Grande Juice ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of
the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For
example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.
The facility conducts preventative maintenance and any necessary minor repairs in house, but an
outside contractor is hired for major repairs or maintenance.
The facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the
International Mechanical Code, ANSI/IIAR 2, and ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 15,
which specifically outline requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.
These safety features include ammonia sensors in the engine rooms as well as sensors in the cold
rooms. In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine rooms and just
outside of the engine rooms (condensers). All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief
valves that are piped to an ammonia diffusion tank.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, Rio Grande Juice has developed a preventive
maintenance program to complete regularly scheduled inspections and tests of the ammonia
refrigeration system as well as repairs as needed to process equipment.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The refrigeration systems at Rio Grande Juice date to 1969.
Preventative maintenance has been kept up throughout the last 5 years. Therefore, there have been
no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in
the past five years. In addition, there have been no injuries resu

lting from an ammonia release, nor
any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Rio Grande Juice facility has an emergency action plan in effect. The Emergency Action Plan
(Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document.

This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:
 1. To save lives.
 2. To minimize and avoid injuries.
 3. To protect the environment.
 4. To minimize property damage.

The facility maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency
coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and notification
procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be
implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan
is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure
compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.

In case of an ammonia emergency, the facility plans to evacuate all employees and contractors and
activate the facility's action plan to respond to the situation. If necessary, they will alert the local
emergency responders (fire department) for assistance. The facility plans to coordinate emergency
response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazards Analysis, conducted on July 30-31, 2013, including a Hazard and Operability
(HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the
Wonderful Citrus facility. The Wonderful Citrus safety committee is planning to complete several
items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their
employees. These changes include the following items:
1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.
2. Continue to have e

mployee involvement in Safety Plan Development.
3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.
4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
